title: Connecticut Home Sells for $50 Million as Seller Departs for Palm Beach; Waterfront Greenwich property was sold by Tremblant Capital's Brett Barakett
text:
The anonymous buyer bought the house through a Delaware-based limited liability company.

Mr. Barakett is founder and chief executive of global asset management fund Tremblant Capital. "Mr. Barakett moved to Palm Beach with his family and is now living there full time, given Tremblant has opened an office in the area," said Mike Geller, a spokesman for Tremblant Capital. In July 2019 Mr. Barakett paid $15.165 million for a house in Palm Beach, records show.

The Greenwich house, designed by Connecticut architecture firm Shope Reno Wharton, has a 60-foot indoor pool. The roughly 2Â½-acre property has 340 feet of frontage on Long Island Sound with a stone jetty and deep-water dock. The grounds also include an outdoor pool, a sports court, vegetable gardens, fruit tree orchards, a chicken coop and an electric vehicle charging station.

Mr. Barakett purchased the land in 2005 and replaced a 1950s-era house with a Georgian-style stone mansion, where the Baraketts were married in 2016. The land was once part of an early 1900s racetrack and was later owned by the late former IBM chief Thomas Watson Jr.

Leslie McElwreath of Sotheby's International Realty, who had the Greenwich listing with colleague Joseph Barbieri, declined to comment. The buyer was represented by Douglas Elliman. Dina Goldentayer, a Douglas Elliman agent in Miami Beach, was a consulting agent.

Luxury homes in Fairfield County, where Greenwich is located, sold for an average of about $3.39 million in the third quarter of 2021, up over 14% compared with the same period last year, according to a report by Douglas Elliman. Greenwich, which saw areal-estate turnaround in the pandemic, had its lowest single-family inventory and highest number of single-family sales on record in the third quarter, according to the report.

Connecticut Home Sells for $50 Million as Seller Departs for Palm Beach
